elements.title: Absorb the Hard Side's Risk Completely Before Asking for Commitment
elements.problem: Hosts are the hard side of Split Lease's network: they contribute disproportionate value (their property) and have disproportionately high expectations. Mahesh circles back to financial risk three separate times during a 13-minute call -- payment guarantee (02:17, 10:45), deposit handling (09:34), and property damage resolution (12:04). Each question is a probe for the same underlying concern: will I lose money? Cold Start Theory identifies that the hard side has 'complex workflows, expects status benefits as well as financial outcomes, and will try competitive products to compare.' Mahesh is already comparing to Furnished Finder (07:29). If Split Lease's risk absorption is perceived as partial -- 'we reduce risk' rather than 'we eliminate risk' -- Mahesh has no reason to switch from the known competitor to the unknown platform. The current journey surfaces guarantees reactively (only when the host asks) rather than proactively eliminating risk as a prerequisite to every commitment request.
elements.solution: Structure every commitment-requesting moment in the journey so that the platform has already demonstrated complete risk absorption BEFORE the commitment is requested. This means: (1) At evaluation, surface the payment guarantee, host guarantee ($1M property damage coverage), and vetting process unprompted, before asking the host to proceed. Do not wait for the host to ask 'what if there's damage?' -- answer it before the question forms. (2) At pricing, show the guarantee inline with the rate confirmation: '$2,600/month -- guaranteed to you regardless of occupancy.' The guarantee is not a separate feature; it is embedded in the price display. (3) At proposal management, the proposal card should lead with risk-absorbed language: 'Vetted guest. Payment guaranteed. $1M property coverage active.' before showing guest details or asking for acceptance. (4) At active lease, the dashboard should show a persistent 'protection status' indicator so the host never has to wonder whether they are covered. The pattern: risk absorption must precede every ask, not follow it.

evidence.quote: Even if you are not able to find this ghost roommate setup, I'm still getting paid whatever first month.
evidence.insight: Mahesh's phrasing reveals his mental model: the ghost roommate is an upside, but the payment guarantee is the baseline. He will not proceed unless the baseline is secured regardless of the optional upside. This is the hard side's minimum condition for forming an atomic network.

evidence.quote: How does the deposit get sorted out? Is that something that I would work with you or would that with the...
evidence.insight: Mahesh probes the dispute resolution counterparty. He needs to know he works with the platform, not with a stranger. The hard side requires the platform to be the risk-absorbing intermediary, not a pass-through.

evidence.quote: Users on the hard side have complex workflows, expect status benefits as well as financial outcomes, and will try competitive products to compare. As a result, their expectations are higher, and it's difficult to engage and retain them.
evidence.insight: Cold Start Theory predicts that the hard side will comparison-shop. Mahesh explicitly comparison-shops against Furnished Finder (07:29). The only way to win the hard side is to offer something the competitor cannot: complete risk absorption that makes the economic outcome unconditional.

evidence.quote: The Economic Effect -- which directly affects a product's business model -- can be improved over time as well, by increasing conversions in key monetization flows and ramping up revenue per user, as the network grows.
evidence.insight: The payment guarantee is Split Lease's Economic Effect made concrete before the network reaches scale. It converts hard-side hosts by eliminating the financial uncertainty that normally requires network density to resolve. This is a pre-scale economic moat.

elements.user_goal: Know with certainty that my income is protected and my property is covered before I agree to anything, without having to ask multiple times.
elements.company_goal: Convert hard-side hosts by removing the financial risk comparison that currently favors incumbents like Furnished Finder, and reduce the number of guarantee-related questions that require agent intervention.
elements.time_budget: Risk absorption information must be visible within the first 10 seconds of any commitment-requesting screen. The host should never need to navigate away from a decision point to find guarantee details.
anti_goals: DO NOT present guarantees as a separate feature or marketing claim. Embed them directly into the context where risk is perceived (pricing display, proposal card, lease dashboard).
DO NOT require the host to ask about risk coverage. If they have to ask, the design has already failed.
DO NOT use vague language like 'we help protect your property.' Use specific, unconditional language: '$1M property damage coverage active on this lease.'
DO NOT bury guarantee terms in a linked document or FAQ. The headline guarantee must be visible inline; the details can be expandable.
elements.success_metric: Reduction in guarantee-related questions to agents during evaluation and proposal phases. Target: fewer than 20% of hosts asking about payment guarantees after the platform surfaces them proactively. Secondary: hard-side conversion rate (evaluation-to-listing) above 50%.

elements.title: Design for the Institutional Gatekeeper as a First-Class Network Participant
elements.problem: Mahesh cannot unilaterally join the Split Lease network. His management company requires an application for every guest (04:25-04:30: 'I probably need that information to share with my management because they do require application'). This creates a structural barrier that Cold Start Theory identifies as analogous to enterprise adoption: 'There are enterprise products like Workday that require the company to implement them before there's any value. Here, a viral growth strategy is difficult, because it's not enough to dribble in a few users at a time.' The atomic network for hosts with management companies is not [Host + Guest + Platform] but [Host + Management Company + Guest + Platform]. The current journey has no workflow, documentation format, or communication channel designed for this third-party gatekeeper. If the management company cannot process Split Lease's guest information through their existing application workflow, the atomic network never forms -- regardless of how convinced Mahesh personally is.
elements.solution: Treat the management company as a network participant with its own onboarding path and information needs. This means: (1) During evaluation, ask the host whether a third-party approval is required. If yes, immediately branch into a gatekeeper-aware workflow. (2) Generate a 'Management Company Package' -- a PDF or shareable link containing the guest's vetted profile, credit check summary, employment verification, intended stay pattern, and Split Lease's guarantee terms, formatted to look like a standard rental application. The format should match what management companies expect, not what Split Lease's internal system generates. (3) During proposal management, add a 'Share with Management' action that sends the package directly to the management company contact with the host CC'd. (4) Track the management company's approval status as a visible pipeline stage: 'Awaiting Management Approval' appears between 'Proposal Sent' and 'Lease Ready.' (5) For hosts who successfully navigate the management company gate once, store the pathway so subsequent guests can be submitted through the same channel with minimal re-effort. This is Chen's domino effect applied to institutional adoption: the first approval creates a pathway that makes every subsequent approval easier.

evidence.quote: I probably need that information to share with my management because they do require application.
evidence.insight: Mahesh introduces the management company as a blocking dependency without hesitation -- this is not a minor concern, it is his standard workflow. The platform must accommodate this workflow or Mahesh cannot proceed regardless of his personal interest.

evidence.quote: Do I have to send most of them to, to find management company I'm here on something that I'll have to, I'll have to figure out?
evidence.insight: Mahesh is uncertain about how to bridge Split Lease's vetting information to his management company's application process. This uncertainty is a friction multiplier: it is not just one unknown, but a cascade of unknowns (what format? what information? who sends it? how long will it take?).

evidence.quote: There are enterprise products like Workday that require the company to implement them before there's any value. Here, a viral growth strategy is difficult, because it's not enough to dribble in a few users at a time.
evidence.insight: The management company is a micro-enterprise that must be 'implemented' (convinced to accept Split Lease's documentation) before the host can derive value. This requires a top-down approach: provide the management company with everything they need in their expected format, rather than asking Mahesh to be the intermediary.

evidence.quote: Each launch makes the next set of adjacent networks easier, and easier, and easier, until the momentum becomes unstoppable -- but it all radiates from a small win at the very start.
evidence.insight: If Mahesh's management company approves one Split Lease guest, the approval pathway is established. Subsequent guests for Mahesh or any host in the same building can reuse this pathway. The management company becomes a tipped node that unlocks an adjacent network of hosts.

elements.user_goal: Provide my management company with everything they need to approve the guest without me becoming the intermediary who reformats and relays information between two systems.
elements.company_goal: Unblock a segment of hosts (those with management companies, HOAs, or co-op boards) who currently cannot convert because the platform lacks a third-party approval workflow. Each management company onboarded creates a reusable pathway for all hosts under that company.
elements.time_budget: The Management Company Package should be generable in under 30 seconds from the proposal screen. The host should not need to manually compile any information -- everything should auto-populate from the guest's vetted profile and the booking terms.
anti_goals: DO NOT make the host the translator between Split Lease and the management company. The platform should generate documentation in the management company's expected format.
DO NOT treat management company approval as an edge case. For professionally managed properties, it is the standard path, not the exception.
DO NOT let management company approval become a black hole. Track it as a visible status in the pipeline so both the host and the agent can see where it stands.
DO NOT require the management company to create a Split Lease account. The shareable package should work via email or link with no login required.
elements.success_metric: Management-gated host conversion rate: percentage of hosts with management companies who complete the evaluation-to-listing flow. Target: within 15% of the conversion rate for hosts without management companies. Secondary: time from proposal to management approval under 5 business days.

elements.title: Surface the Ghost Roommate Economic Upside Without Hiding the Operational Complexity
elements.problem: The ghost roommate concept is Split Lease's highest-leverage differentiator -- it can double the economic yield of a single property by filling weekday and weekend slots with different guests. But Mahesh's reaction reveals a dual response: economic interest ('even if you are not able to find this ghost roommate setup, I'm still getting paid' at 10:45) mixed with operational anxiety ('I've never dealt with that kind of a situation, obviously it comes with little complications' at 08:31). Cold Start Theory identifies this as a 'Hitting the Ceiling' dynamic: 'a rapidly growing network wants to both grow as well as tear itself apart, and there are enormous forces in both directions.' The ghost roommate feature accelerates the tipping point (more economic value per atomic network) but also introduces context collapse (two guests, two schedules, shared cleaning, overlapping stays). If the platform surfaces the economic upside without honestly addressing the operational complexity, hosts who encounter complications during the active lease will feel misled and churn. If it leads with the complexity, hosts will never reach the tipping point.
elements.solution: Present the ghost roommate concept using a 'guaranteed floor with visible upside' framing that honestly addresses complexity. This means: (1) During evaluation, introduce ghost roommates as an optional accelerator, not a requirement: 'Your guaranteed rate is $2,600/month. If we find a weekend guest, your total earnings could increase to $X/month.' The guarantee is the floor; the ghost roommate is the ceiling. (2) During pricing, show a clear economic comparison: single-guest income vs. ghost-roommate income, with the additional operational responsibilities listed transparently alongside the additional income. The host should see both the money and the work. (3) During active lease, if a ghost roommate match is found, present a dedicated 'Ghost Roommate Preview' that shows: the proposed weekend guest's profile, the specific cleaning handoff protocol, the schedule overlap (if any), and the incremental income -- all in one view. The host decides with full information. (4) Provide a 'Ghost Roommate Operations Guide' that is specific to the host's property and stay pattern, not a generic FAQ. Include the cleaning transition times, key handoff procedures, and a clear escalation path for issues. (5) Make the ghost roommate opt-in at every stage, with an easy opt-out that does not affect the base guarantee.

evidence.quote: I've never dealt with that kind of a situation, obviously it comes with little complications.
evidence.insight: Mahesh's word 'complications' is a System 1 flag. He has pattern-matched the ghost roommate concept to 'complex thing I have never done,' which triggers risk aversion. The platform must convert 'complications' into 'managed processes' by showing exactly how each complication is handled.

evidence.quote: Even if you are not able to find this ghost roommate setup, I'm still getting paid whatever first month.
evidence.insight: Mahesh's first concern about ghost roommates is not operational -- it is financial. He needs to know the base guarantee holds regardless. Once the floor is secured, he can consider the upside. The framing must always be: guaranteed floor first, optional upside second.

evidence.quote: A rapidly growing network wants to both grow as well as tear itself apart, and there are enormous forces in both directions. This is when a network 'hits the ceiling,' and growth stalls.
evidence.insight: Ghost roommate matching increases network value but also introduces the context collapse and complexity that Chen identifies as ceiling-hitting forces. The feature must be designed to capture the growth force while mitigating the destructive force.

evidence.quote: There's fraudsters, overcrowding, and context collapse -- all natural outcomes of a network that grows and matures.
evidence.insight: Two guests sharing one property across the week is a form of context collapse: the host's mental model of 'my tenant' must now accommodate two people, two schedules, and two relationships. The platform must prevent this from overwhelming the host by making the two-guest arrangement feel like a single managed workflow, not two separate tenancies.

elements.user_goal: Understand exactly what the ghost roommate arrangement means for my income AND my responsibilities before I opt in, and feel confident that I can opt out without losing my base guarantee.
elements.company_goal: Maximize ghost roommate adoption among hosts by converting operational anxiety into operational confidence, increasing per-property revenue and strengthening the economic moat against competitors who cannot offer the same arrangement.
elements.time_budget: The ghost roommate explanation should take no more than 60 seconds to read/absorb during evaluation. The Ghost Roommate Preview during active lease should present the full picture (guest profile, schedule, cleaning, income) in a single scrollable view, consumable in under 90 seconds.
anti_goals: DO NOT present ghost roommates as the default expectation. It is an optional economic accelerator, not a required feature of the Split Lease model.
DO NOT hide the operational complexity to make the economic pitch more appealing. Hosts who discover complexity during the active lease will feel deceived.
DO NOT make ghost roommate opt-out difficult or punitive. The host should be able to decline a ghost roommate match without any impact on their base lease or guarantee.

DO NOT present the ghost roommate as a single decision. Break it into stages: interest (evaluation), preview (when a match is found), acceptance (with full operational details), and ongoing management (with clear support channels).
elements.success_metric: Ghost roommate opt-in rate among eligible hosts: percentage of hosts offered a ghost roommate match who accept after seeing the full preview. Target: above 40%. Secondary: ghost roommate churn rate (hosts who opt in then opt out within 30 days) below 15%.

elements.title: Define and Instrument the Three-Month Atomic Network Stability Threshold
elements.problem: Ariel's initial commitment is 3 months with intent to extend ('start with three months and then ideally extend if it was something that worked for her' at 03:26). Cold Start Theory identifies that every network has a stability threshold: for Slack, it was 2,000 messages, after which 93% of customers retained. For Uber, it was getting ETAs under 3 minutes. For Airbnb, it was 300 listings with 100 reviewed. Split Lease has no defined stability threshold for its atomic network (host + guest + platform). The 3-month initial lease is the natural candidate: approximately 12-13 weekly stays, each of which is a moment where the atomic network either strengthens or weakens. But the platform currently treats the active lease as a monolithic period rather than a sequence of measurable engagement moments that accumulate toward a stability threshold. Without a defined threshold and instrumentation to track progress toward it, the platform cannot identify at-risk leases before they fail to renew.
elements.solution: Define the 3-month initial lease as Split Lease's atomic network stability test and instrument it accordingly. This means: (1) Identify the key engagement signals that correlate with lease extension: on-time payments received, host logins to the dashboard, guest check-in/check-out compliance, host-guest communication frequency, date change requests handled smoothly, and host satisfaction signals (e.g., response time to messages). (2) Create a 'Network Health Score' for each active lease that aggregates these signals into a single metric visible to the operations team (not necessarily to the host). A declining score triggers proactive outreach before the host decides not to renew. (3) Design the active lease period with deliberate engagement moments at weeks 2, 6, and 10 that check in with the host, surface the cumulative value delivered (total payments received, property protection events avoided), and prime the extension conversation. (4) At the 3-month mark, present the host with a 'Lease Performance Summary' that shows concrete outcomes: total income earned, on-time payment record, property protection status, and the guest's review/rating if applicable. This converts the abstract question 'should I extend?' into a concrete evidence-based decision. (5) Track whether hosts who survive 3 months retain at rates comparable to Slack's 93% post-threshold retention. If not, refine the threshold definition.

evidence.quote: Start with three months and then ideally extend if it was something that worked for her.
evidence.insight: The phrase 'if it was something that worked' is a conditional evaluation. Ariel (and by extension, Mahesh) will assess the arrangement against a success standard at the 3-month mark. The platform must define what 'worked' means in measurable terms and proactively demonstrate it.

evidence.quote: I've never heard of this company... I guess you're doing experience similar to Furnished Finder.
evidence.insight: Mahesh has zero prior relationship with Split Lease. The 3-month lease is his entire evaluation window. Every friction point during this period is not just an inconvenience -- it is evidence for the 'should I stay or should I go back to Furnished Finder?' decision.

evidence.quote: After 2,000 messages, 93% of those customers are still using Slack today.
evidence.insight: Slack identified a specific, measurable threshold beyond which retention became near-certain. Split Lease must identify its equivalent. The 3-month initial lease (12-13 weekly stays) is the strongest candidate. If the host survives 3 months with a positive cumulative experience, the switching cost to Furnished Finder becomes too high.

evidence.quote: Small, sub-scale networks naturally want to self-destruct, because when people show up to a product and none of their friends or coworkers are using it, they will naturally leave.
evidence.insight: During the first 3 months, Mahesh's atomic network is sub-scale (one host, one guest, no adjacent hosts). Anti-network effects are strongest here. The platform must actively counteract these forces by demonstrating cumulative value at regular intervals, not waiting until the renewal decision to make the case.

elements.user_goal: See clear, cumulative evidence that this arrangement is working -- payments received, property protected, guest well-behaved -- so I can make a confident decision about extending.
elements.company_goal: Increase lease extension rates by identifying and addressing at-risk leases before the 3-month renewal point, and by presenting hosts with concrete evidence of the atomic network's stability at the moment of the renewal decision.
elements.time_budget: The Lease Performance Summary at the 3-month mark should be consumable in under 2 minutes. Mid-lease check-ins (weeks 2, 6, 10) should take the host no more than 30 seconds each to read and optionally respond.
anti_goals: DO NOT wait until the renewal decision to surface cumulative value. By then, the host's impression is already formed. Proactively surface value throughout the lease.

DO NOT make the check-ins feel like surveys or feedback requests. They should feel like personalized status updates: 'You've received $7,800 in guaranteed payments over 10 weeks. Your property protection is active.'
DO NOT treat all leases as equally at risk. Instrument the Network Health Score so that operational attention is concentrated on leases showing declining engagement signals.
DO NOT use the 3-month threshold as a rigid rule. It is a starting hypothesis to be refined with data. Some markets or host types may have shorter or longer stability thresholds.
elements.success_metric: Lease extension rate: percentage of 3-month initial leases that extend beyond the initial term. Target: above 70%. Secondary: correlation between Network Health Score at week 8 and extension decision, with a predictive accuracy above 80%.

elements.title: Scale Agent-Mediated Trust by Encoding It Into Platform Artifacts
elements.problem: Across the entire Mahesh call, trust is built exclusively by Bryant. Bryant explains vetting (02:17), guarantees (02:17, 11:01), agreements (11:47), cleaning protocols (08:44), host guarantee (12:21), and ghost roommates (07:34). The platform is mentioned exactly once, as a delivery mechanism: 'I can basically get the account set up and then a lot of that information can just be sent to you right through there' (05:05). Cold Start Theory shows this is the expected pattern during the Cold Start stage -- Slack's Stewart Butterfield personally handled 10,000 tweets per month and 8,000 customer support tickets. But Chen is explicit that this does not scale past the tipping point. Bryant's manual trust-building works for tens of hosts; it cannot work for thousands. The platform must eventually replicate Bryant's information density, contextual responsiveness, and authority without Bryant being present. Currently, there is no mechanism to encode what Bryant says into persistent platform artifacts that scale independently.
elements.solution: Systematically encode every trust-building statement Bryant makes into reusable platform artifacts that deliver the same information with the same authority. This means: (1) Create a 'Trust Dossier' for each guest that contains everything Bryant would say about them: vetting status, credit check result, employment, references, stay pattern, and the agent's personal endorsement note. This dossier appears on the proposal card and is shareable with management companies. (2) Build a 'Guarantee Dashboard' that persistently displays all active protections (payment guarantee status, host guarantee coverage, deposit held) so the host never needs to ask 'am I covered?' -- the answer is always visible. (3) Encode Bryant's explanations of complex features (ghost roommates, cleaning protocols, deposit process) into contextual tooltips and inline explanations that appear at the exact moment the host encounters these features. Not a help center, not an FAQ -- inline, contextual, at the point of need. (4) Give the agent a 'handoff note' field that appears on the host's first platform screen: 'Bryant's note: Hi Mahesh, great talking with you. I've set up your account with the property details we discussed. Ariel's vetted profile is ready for your review.' This transfers the human trust to the digital context. (5) As the network tips and more hosts join, collect the patterns from agent conversations to continuously refine the platform's automated trust artifacts.

evidence.quote: If I can grab your email, I can basically get the account set up and then a lot of that information can just be sent to you right through there.
evidence.insight: Bryant frames the platform as a channel for information delivery, not a trust source. The platform must become a trust source in its own right, or it will always depend on Bryant to establish credibility before the host will engage with it.

evidence.quote: Has been vetted and went through our vetting process, including like a credit check. So that's been taken care of as well.
evidence.insight: Bryant compresses the entire vetting value proposition into two sentences. The platform must deliver this same information with the same density and authority. A badge that says 'Vetted' without context is not equivalent to Bryant's explanation. The platform artifact must include: what was checked, when, and what the result was.

evidence.quote: Stewart personally handled the lion's share of 10,000 tweets per month and 8,000 customer support tickets.
evidence.insight: Slack's founder personally managed early user trust. This was essential during the Cold Start stage but had to be encoded into the product to scale. Bryant is in the same position. His individual trust-building must be captured as product artifacts that work without him.

evidence.quote: As a network grows, each new network starts to tip faster and faster, so that the entire market is more easily captured.
evidence.insight: The tipping point accelerates only if the trust-building process also accelerates. If every new host requires a personal Bryant call, the tipping point speed is limited by Bryant's calendar. Encoding trust into platform artifacts is what allows the tipping speed to increase with each new host.

elements.user_goal: Find the same depth of information and reassurance on the platform that I received from Bryant on the phone, without needing to call anyone.
elements.company_goal: Decouple host acquisition from individual agent capacity by encoding agent trust into scalable platform artifacts, enabling the network to tip faster as new markets are entered.
elements.time_budget: The Trust Dossier should be reviewable in under 60 seconds. The Guarantee Dashboard should be glanceable in under 10 seconds. Contextual explanations should appear inline and add no more than 5 seconds to read at the point of need.
anti_goals: DO NOT replace the agent entirely during the Cold Start stage. The agent is still essential for initial conversion. The goal is to encode trust for scale, not to remove humans prematurely.
DO NOT create a generic help center as a substitute for contextual trust artifacts. A help center requires the host to search for answers; the platform must deliver answers before they are sought.
DO NOT present vetting information as a binary badge ('Vetted'). Show what was checked, when, and what the outcome was. The badge is a summary; the detail must be one click away.
DO NOT let the agent's handoff note be optional. Every host who has had a phone call should see a personalized note from their agent on their first platform visit.
elements.success_metric: Agent-to-platform trust transfer rate: percentage of hosts who complete their first platform action (view proposal, begin listing) without contacting the agent for clarification. Target: above 65%. Secondary: reduction in post-call agent questions per host from current baseline by 40%.

elements.title: Use the First Successful Lease to Tip Adjacent Networks Within the Same Building or Management Company
elements.problem: Mahesh has a management company, which implies a multi-unit property or a portfolio of properties under centralized management. Cold Start Theory's domino effect states that 'each launch makes the next set of adjacent networks easier, and easier, and easier, until the momentum becomes unstoppable -- but it all radiates from a small win at the very start.' If Mahesh's first lease succeeds, it creates not just a retained host, but a pathway into every other property under the same management company. However, the platform currently has no mechanism to leverage a successful lease as a seed for adjacent networks. The management company's approval pathway, once established, could be reused for other hosts. Mahesh's positive experience could be referenced when approaching other hosts in the same building. But without deliberate design for this domino effect, each new host in the same building starts from zero -- repeating the management company approval, the trust-building call, and the evaluation process as if no prior lease had ever occurred.
elements.solution: Design the post-first-lease experience to deliberately tip adjacent networks. This means: (1) After a successful first lease (defined as: 3 months completed, payments on time, no unresolved disputes), ask the host: 'Do you have other units or know other hosts who might benefit from Split Lease?' Provide a one-click referral mechanism with a pre-written message the host can send. (2) For management-company-gated hosts, store the management company's approval pathway (contact person, required documentation format, approval timeline) as a reusable template. When another host under the same management company inquires, the platform can say: 'Your management company has already approved Split Lease guests. Here is the approved process.' This eliminates the gatekeeper barrier for subsequent hosts. (3) Create a 'Building Network' or 'Management Company Network' view for the operations team that shows all hosts under the same management entity and their conversion status. This makes the adjacent-network opportunity visible and actionable. (4) In markets approaching the tipping point, prioritize outreach to hosts under management companies that have already approved Split Lease, since the conversion path is already cleared. (5) Track the domino metric: for each management company that approves the first host, how many additional hosts convert within 6 months?

evidence.quote: I probably need that information to share with my management because they do require application.
evidence.insight: The management company is both a barrier and a lever. Once cleared, it becomes a reusable pathway. But this only works if the platform remembers and reuses the pathway, rather than treating each host under the same management company as a new cold start.

evidence.quote: I've never heard of this company.
evidence.insight: Mahesh discovered Split Lease through direct outreach, not organic awareness. This means there is no ambient network effect in his market yet. His successful lease is the seed from which ambient awareness could grow -- but only if the platform deliberately leverages it.

evidence.quote: Each launch makes the next set of adjacent networks easier, and easier, and easier, until the momentum becomes unstoppable -- but it all radiates from a small win at the very start.
evidence.insight: Chen's domino effect is the theoretical foundation for this pattern. Mahesh's successful lease is the first domino. The management company pathway is the hinge that connects it to adjacent dominos. Without deliberate design, the hinge is not stored and the chain reaction does not occur.

evidence.quote: Once a single atomic network can be built, it becomes straightforward to build many others by repeating the same playbook.
evidence.insight: The playbook for Mahesh's management company is: identify contact, submit documentation in required format, receive approval, proceed with lease. If this playbook is stored and reusable, every subsequent host under the same management company inherits a pre-cleared path. The Cold Start Problem for adjacent hosts is already partially solved.

elements.user_goal: If I have a good experience, easily recommend Split Lease to other hosts in my building or under my management company without them having to start from scratch.
elements.company_goal: Accelerate the tipping point in local markets by converting each successful lease into a seed for adjacent host acquisition, with management company pathways as reusable infrastructure that reduces the cost and time of subsequent conversions.
elements.time_budget: The referral mechanism should take the host under 30 seconds to trigger. The management company pathway reuse should be invisible to the new host -- they should simply experience a faster, smoother onboarding because the pathway was already cleared.
anti_goals: DO NOT ask for referrals before the first lease has proven successful. Premature referral requests signal desperation and can damage the host's confidence in the platform.
DO NOT treat each host under the same management company as an independent cold start. The second host should have a materially easier path than the first.

DO NOT rely on organic word-of-mouth. Design the referral mechanism into the platform with a specific trigger (successful lease completion) and a specific action (one-click referral with pre-populated message).
DO NOT expose the management company pathway data to hosts. It is an operational tool for the platform team, not a host-facing feature.
elements.success_metric: Adjacent network conversion rate: for each management company that approves the first Split Lease host, the number of additional hosts converted within 6 months. Target: at least 1 additional host per management company within 6 months. Secondary: time from first host approval to second host listing under the same management company below 60 days.
